channel.title: INtech
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from INtech, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Companies Might Soon Have to Tell You When Their Products Will Die
item.description: If everything’s computer, it would be nice to know how long computer last.

item.title: How to Set Up Your New iPhone (2025)
item.description: Welcome to your new Apple smartphone. Here’s how to get the most out of it right out of the box.

item.title: The United States of Elon Musk Inc.
item.description: The degree to which Donald Trump and Elon Musk’s interests are intertwined is unprecedented—and ultimately unsustainable.

item.title: Meghan Markle is launching a podcast about female founders

item.title: Researchers Propose a Better Way to Report Dangerous AI Flaws
item.description: After identifying major flaws in popular AI models, researchers are pushing for a new system to identify and report bugs.

item.title: Apple’s Lockdown Mode is good for security — but its notifications are baffling
item.description: Lockdown Mode is an "extreme protection" feature that's good for at-risk users, but its notifications are increasingly confusing. © 2024 TechCrunch. A...

item.title: Facebook now lets creators get paid for views on stories
item.description: Facebook is rolling out the ability for creators to earn money for views on public stories. The new monetization option is available globally to creat...

item.title: Google wants Gemini to get to know you better
item.description: In the AI chatbot wars, Google thinks the key to retaining users is serving up content they can’t get elsewhere, like answers shaped by their internet...

item.title: OpenAI calls DeepSeek ‘state-controlled,’ calls for bans on ‘PRC-produced’ models
item.description: In a new policy proposal, OpenAI describes Chinese AI lab DeepSeek as “state-subsidized” and “state-controlled,” and recommends that the U.S. governme...

item.title: Sony’s Dazzling New RGB LED TV Comes in 2026
item.description: Sony’s incoming RGB tech joins Hisense and Samsung in the race to define the future of LED TVs.
